findings.title: ST - Stop Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop contracts from transactions and sales for all users excluding the owner by calling specific functions or setting certain variables to zero, which can lead to a honeypot scenario.

findings.title: OCTD - Owner Contract Tokens Drain
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop contracts from transactions and may take advantage of it by calling the `setIsBot` function.

findings.title: ELFM - Exceed Limit Fees Manipulation
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to increase over the allowed limit of 25% by calling the `setTaxFeePercent` function with a high percentage value.

findings.title: BC - Blacklisted Contracts
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop contracts from transactions and may take advantage of it by calling the `setIsBot` function.

findings.title: L01 - Public Function could be Declared External
L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: Solidity defines a naming convention that should be followed.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: There are segments that contain unused state variables.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Detected missing events for critical arithmetic parameters. There are functions that have no event emitted, so it is difficult to track off-chain changes.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: The comparison to boolean constants is redundant. Boolean constants can be used directly and do not need to be compared to true or false.

findings.title: L12 - Using Variables before Declaration
findings.description: The contract is using a variable before the declaration. This is usually happening either if it has not been declared yet or the variable has been declared in a different scope.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of precision.
